title: Free Energy Principle Overview
description: Introduction to the Free Energy Principle as a unifying theory of brain function, perception, and action.
learning_objectives: State the Free Energy Principle mathematically
Understand free energy as prediction error
Connect FEP to information theory and Bayesian inference
Explain how FEP unifies perception and action

content.overview: The Free Energy Principle (FEP) is a theoretical framework that explains how biological systems maintain their integrity by minimizing a quantity called 'free energy'. It provides a unifying account of brain function, perception, learning, and behavior.

core_principle.statement: All biological systems minimize their free energy to maintain their structural and functional integrity.
core_principle.interpretation: Free energy decreases over time (or stays constant in equilibrium)

free_energy_definition.prediction_error: Free energy bounds surprise: F ≥ -log p(x)
free_energy_definition.interpretation: Free energy is an upper bound on surprise (negative log likelihood)

key_components.name: Generative Models
key_components.description: Internal models that predict sensory inputs

key_components.name: Variational Density
key_components.description: Approximate posterior distribution over model parameters
key_components.role: Represents current beliefs about the world

perception_as_inference.principle: Perception is the process of inferring the causes of sensory input
perception_as_inference.mechanism: Update internal model to minimize free energy

action_as_inference.principle: Action is the process of selecting actions to fulfill predictions
action_as_inference.mechanism: Select actions that minimize expected free energy
action_as_inference.outcome: Actions change the world to match predictions

biological_implications.description: Brain minimizes free energy through hierarchical predictive coding
Natural selection favors free energy minimizing organisms
Phenomenal experience arises from free energy minimization

mathematical_connections.information_theory: Free energy bounds surprise and information gain
mathematical_connections.bayesian_inference: Free energy minimization implements Bayesian updating
mathematical_connections.variational_methods: FEP uses variational approximation for inference

examples.name: Visual Perception
examples.description: Brain predicts visual input and updates beliefs based on errors
examples.process: Retinal signals → prediction errors → belief updating → refined predictions

examples.name: Motor Control
examples.description: Motor commands selected to minimize predicted proprioceptive errors
examples.process: Intended movement → predicted sensations → action → error correction

examples.name: Homeostatic Regulation
examples.description: Body maintains temperature by minimizing physiological prediction errors
examples.process: Set point → prediction → deviation → corrective action

interactive_exercises.description: Interactive simulation of free energy minimization
Calculate prediction errors for simple generative models

common_misconceptions.misconception: Free energy is the same as thermodynamic free energy
common_misconceptions.clarification: Variational free energy is information-theoretic, not thermodynamic

common_misconceptions.misconception: FEP only applies to brain function
common_misconceptions.clarification: FEP applies to all biological self-organization
FEP operates at all levels, from cells to conscious brains
